posts.name: Mahir
posts.cooked: My team has an elevator capable of scoring up to L3. We are considering upgrading its height to reach L4 and potentially the net. How can we enhance our elevator to achieve our goal? One idea is to add stages to the elevator. Currently, we are using an SDS elevator.

posts.name: Sameer
posts.cooked: How many stages do you currently have on your elevator?

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked: Assuming the scoring mechanism is located on the innermost part of the elevator, positioning it higher does not alter the overall height during descent. Conversely, when the elevator ascends, the scoring mechanism will be raised above ground level.

posts.name: hrench
posts.cooked:
If you’re still using robots built by others for the competition on April 8, you’re likely not going to perform well. Success at Champs depends on whether you invest time in improving your robot continuously through the season. While it’s tempting to rely on a big-name team picking you over others, focusing on your robot’s capabilities and areas for improvement can lead to better results. However, neglecting these aspects might result in missing opportunities to excel.

Building and maintaining a robot requires effort and attention to detail. With the season often filled with distractions like prom, job deadlines, and warmer weather activities, it’s easy to lose focus. If you’re serious about doing well, prioritize improving your robot, especially in areas where it can excel or grow. While some may argue against this, it’s worth considering because failing to address known issues can lead to discouragement, as seen in past experiences when teams didn’t prepare a practice bot and struggled with unresolved problems.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Bob Hrenchir, mechanical build mentor, team 1108, Paola, KS

posts.name: Andrew
posts.cooked:
I don’t know if you’re going to Champs or not, but I’ll make a list for both scenarios. If you *are* going to Champs, I highly recommend against upgrading the elevator. While L4 and Barge are essential right now, the time until Champs is brief. Adding a new stage to extend your elevator comes with significant risks—like needing to manufacture new parts, possibly purchasing them, rewiring, and programming. Plus, there are numerous factors that could affect your robot’s performance if you rush to build the elevator, leading to inconsistency, which may not be desired in alliances.

If you’re *not* going to Champs, consider the trade-offs. Skipping the elevator upgrade saves you time and effort for other activities, like excursions outside of robotics or saving parts for next year. However, upgrading the elevator could serve as a valuable offseason project to introduce new members to exciting new skills.

I hope this helps clarify the situation!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5013 Pit Crew and Design (I do not speak for my team, just my opinions)

posts.name: Mahir
posts.cooked: Our team reached state but did not qualify for worlds. Potential strategies for improving our performance at the upcoming Invitational competition in October have been proposed, aiming to enhance our scoring capabilities during that event.

posts.name: Mahir
posts.cooked: I also think that it's a good offseason project because for almost any pick and place game, you will need an elevator.

posts.name: Mahir
posts.cooked: We have three of them, but have resolved the issue. We just need to obtain longer aluminum tubings for moving higher, as we already have all other required components.

posts.name: Riley Brewer
posts.cooked: It looks like you have a 2-stage elevator, so you’d need to extend the height of both stages. I think your carriage can probably stay the same, which preserves the geometry of the funnel handoff to the end effector.
